info.title: Unisys Stealth Ecosystem API Programming Reference Guide
info.description:
This displays best with the following browsers: Chrome, Firefox, and Microsoft Edge.

# Getting Started
**Note**: this tutorial does not necessarily represent best practices for the programming language, such as using global variables which is generally not recommended. The purpose of this tutorial is simply to get you started and familiar with the EcoAPI.

The Stealth Ecosystem API (EcoAPI) is a REST API that enables users to query and interact with their Stealth environment programmatically using simple HTTP requests. An API, or Application Programming Interface, allows programs to interact with each other in a consistent manner by utilizing a common interface. REST stands for Representational State Transfer. A REST API is one such common interface where API calls are made using HTTP requests.

This guide contains a short tutorial to get you started, general information about the EcoAPI, and specific EcoAPI request information.

HTTP requests can be made:
- in a browser (only GET requests)
- using our [PowerShell cmdlets](./#section/General-Information/PowerShell-cmdlets)
- with a tool such as [Postman](https://www.getpostman.com/) or [Insomnia](https://insomnia.rest/)
- programmatically in a script

If you are working on the Management Server itself, the [PowerShell cmdlets](./#section/General-Information/PowerShell-cmdlets) are the easiest to use. Open a PowerShell console session and enter the commands.

If you are new to REST APIs in general, we strongly recommend using a tool such as [Postman](https://www.getpostman.com/) or [Insomnia](https://insomnia.rest/). Referencing this documentation, you can enter the HTTP method, URL, authentication, and request body to make a request.

Once you are familiar with the REST API, you can start automating tasks with your own code. We have several example scripts in PowerShell, Python, and Ruby but all programming languages capable of making a web request can work.

## The Browser
We will start with a simple request to determine the version of the EcoAPI service that is running on the Management Server. Visit the following link in the browser on the Management Server:
```
https://localhost:8448/uisStealth/EcoApi/latest/version
```
The response displays the EcoAPI version represented in XML format. All GET requests can be made through the browser, but all GET requests besides `/version` require authentication. To make requests directly from your computer, instead of directly on the Management Server, replace `localhost` with the IP address of your Management Server. The default port is `8448`, but if the Management Server software was installed with a different port, use that port instead.

Now try to view the configuration resources. Replace `version` with `configuration` in the URL as follows:
```
https://localhost:8448/uisStealth/EcoApi/latest/configuration
```
For this request, you will be prompted to enter the Enterprise Manager administrator credentials. Once credentials are supplied, the response displays all the information about your Stealth configurations.

This response details all of the configurations, but it does not display much about the roles or other child resources. Copy one of the configuration unique identifiers (IDs), say for example, `B1424D98-E57A-A08E-AB90-C8248B9DC4E9`. Request the complete configuration by going to this URL in your browser:
```
https://localhost:8448/uisStealth/EcoApi/latest/configuration/B1424D98-E57A-A08E-AB90-C8248B9DC4E9?recursive=true
```
The resulting response details information about all of the resources that are associated with this configuration. If you have a lot of resources, this could take some time. Only use "recursive" when needed, and be careful using it without specifying a unique identifier.

Issuing requests through use of the browser provides a quick way to view your Stealth resources. If you want to create, update, or delete Stealth resources, we recommend you use a dedicated REST API client, our PowerShell cmdlets, or your own custom script.

## PowerShell cmdlets
Now that we know how to get resources, we can create some.

Open a PowerShell console session on the Management Server. Before issuing any commands, you need to run [Connect-StealthServer](./ecoapi-powershell-docs/Unisys.Stealth/Unisys.Stealth.EcoApi/Connect-StealthServer.html). To do so, enter the following command in the PowerShell console session:
```powershell
Connect-StealthServer localhost -Credential (Get-Credential) -TrustCert
```
You can tab complete in the PowerShell console. Try partially typing the cmdlet name and press tab until you find the right one. You can do the same for cmdlet parameters by typing "-" and then tab.

The resulting response displays the hostname, port, and username. Note that you must run that command again if you open a new PowerShell terminal instance. If you want to use the Unisys-supplied PowerShell cmdlets on another system, follow the steps in the [PowerShell cmdlets](./#section/General-Information/PowerShell-cmdlets) section.

Each request in this guide links to the associated cmdlet documentation. By referring to [create filter list](#operation/createFilterSet), you can see that the cmdlet for creating a filter list is [New-StealthFilterList](./ecoapi-powershell-docs/Unisys.Stealth/Unisys.Stealth.EcoApi/New-StealthFilterList.html).

Enter the following commands:
```powershell
$filter = New-StealthQualifiedFilter -IpAddress "1.1.1.1"
$filterList = New-StealthFilterList -Name "Test cmdlets create" -Description "This was created as part of the EcoAPI tutorial." -Children $filter
```
You just created your first Stealth resource. The first line constructs the filter object so we include it under the filter list. The second line creates the filter list and the filter, and returns the created filter list with the filter.

Try getting the filter list from the browser as described earlier in this section. You then see the newly created resources. If you want to get the filter list using the cmdlets, run the following command:
```powershell
Get-StealthFilterList -Id $filterList.Id
```
That was pretty painless, but what about automating these tasks? We will go over scripting in the next section, but if PowerShell is your programming language of choice, we encourage you to put these PowerShell commands into a .ps1 file and try running the PowerShell script you just created.

## Python
Use of scripts enable you to automate common tasks. You can make HTTP requests to the EcoAPI in any programming language. In fact, that is what our PowerShell cmdlets do behind the scenes. This section provides detailed information about:
- Making an HTTP request programmatically
- Formatting the request body in JSON
- Request status and response handling
- Authorization handling
- Error handling

For reference, the link below provides access to the final version of the script we create in this section (To save, right-click the link below and select "Save target as"):
- [tutorial.py](./examples/python/tutorial.py)

### Installing Python
Visit [python.org](https://python.org) to download the latest version of Python 3, and install Python.

You can start using the Python Shell right away, but we will be using the terminal, which is also known as the command prompt. Add your Python path and pip path to the end of your `Path` environment variable and, replace `<user>` with the user you are logged into the computer as. You can search for `environment variable` in Windows.
```
;C:\Users\<user>\AppData\Local\Programs\Python\Python38-32
;C:\Users\<user>\AppData\Local\Programs\Python\Python38-32\Scripts
```
The paths are separated by semicolons, which is why they are placed at the beginning. Click OK, and close the environment variables window. That is it for the set up. Now we test it.

Open a command prompt and type the following:
```
python
```
You now see `>>>` at the left of your cursor. Enter `Ctrl-z` to exit the Python Shell.
### Running a Python Program
Create a file and name it `myfile.py`. You can use [Notepad++](https://notepad-plus-plus.org), [Visual Studio Code](https://code.visualstudio.com), or another editor or IDE to edit your Python file.

Now add something to our file:
```python
# Imports
import requests
```
This imports the `requests` Python library so that we can easily make HTTP requests in our script. Save the file.

In the terminal navigate to the directory your file is in. For example, if your file is on the Desktop, type `cd Desktop` or `cd C:\users\<user>\desktop`. Run your program:
```
python myfile.py
```
You will notice an error message stating that you do not have the `requests` library. You can install the `requests` Python library with the Python package manager, pip, in the terminal:
```
pip install requests
```
Once that is done, run your program again:
```
python myfile.py
```
The error message does not appear. You will need to use pip to install three other libraries as you progress through this tutorial.
### Authorization Handling
Now that we know how to run a Python program and import libraries, we need to be able to enter our credentials. We can create a function to get arguments from the command line.
```python
# Imports
...
import argparse

# Suppress warnings
import urllib3
urllib3.disable_warnings(urllib3.exceptions.InsecureRequestWarning)

def parse_args():
    """
    Parses the command line args for common arguments and returns them formatted for use.
    """
    # Parse the arguments
    parser = argparse.ArgumentParser(add_help=False)
    parser.add_argument('-h', '--host', help='The hostname or IP address of the computer running the EcoAPI service')
    parser.add_argument('-n', '--port', help='The port number that the EcoAPI service is running on')
    parser.add_argument('-u', '--user', help='The EcoAPI user name')
    parser.add_argument('-p', '--password', help='The EcoAPI user password')

    # Put the arguments into a dictionary for easy access
    args = vars(parser.parse_args())

    # Format the authorization and base URI
    auth = (args['user'], args['password'])
    base_uri = "https://{}:{}/uisStealth/EcoAPI/latest".format(args['host'], args['port'])
    return auth, base_uri
```
**Important**: Note that Python uses indentation as syntax. Be sure the function
 contents are indented with spaces as shown. Alternatively, you can use tabs,
 but do not mix spaces and tabs.

After the function, type the following:
```python
# Start of execution
auth, base_uri = parse_args()
print("User name = " + auth[0] + "\nBase URI = " + base_uri)
```
Be sure it is left justified (no spaces). To test the function, save the file, and run it, passing in the host, port, user name, and password:
```
python myFile.py --host localhost --port 8448 --user <user name> --password <password>
```
You should see these values printed out, except the password. Add default values so that you do not have to type that every time:
```python
def parse_args():
    ...
    args = vars(parser.parse_args())

    # Use default values if the argument was not provided
    args['host'] = args['host'] if args['host'] != None else "localhost"
    args['port'] = args['port'] if args['port'] != None else "8448"
    args['user'] = args['user'] if args['user'] != None else "<user name>"

    # Format the authorization and base URI
    ...
```
Feel free to add a default value for the password. However, it is safer not to store your password. Save the file and test these changes by entering the following command:
```
python myFile.py -p <password>
```
### The GET Request and Responses
We are ready to start making EcoAPI requests. After the `parse_args()` function, create the `get_resource()` function:
```python
# Imports
...
import json
import requests
...

def get_resource(uri):
    """
    Gets a resource using the given URI and returns the resource.
    """
    print("Getting resource using URI:\n{}\n".format(uri))
    response = requests.get(uri, auth=auth, headers=headers, verify=False)
    return response.json()

# Start of execution
...
headers = {'accept': 'application/json'}
```
The `get()` function is part of the requests Python library. We pass the URI to it similar to how we typed the URI in the browser to get resources. We also pass our credentials in the auth variable. The headers variable specifies what format we want back. The browser returned the resources back in XML, and here we are using JSON.

Call `get_resource()` from a new function called `main()`. We are going to put all our main functionality in `main()`. This makes it easier to handle errors later as well:
```python
def get_resource(uri):
    ...

def main():
    uri = base_uri + '/filterList'
    response = get_resource(uri)
    print("The get response: {}".format(json.dumps(response, indent=4, separators=(',', ': '))))

...
headers = {'accept': 'application/json'}
main()
```
Test this by running the program the same way we did before. You can see all the filter lists on the Management Server represented in JSON. Also notice how we are able to print the entire JSON response in one line.

### Error Handling
What happens if something goes wrong? Maybe the URI has a typo or the credentials are wrong. There are many ways to handle errors, but we are simply going to print out the errors so we can see the message.

Add the following code around the call to `main()`:
```python
...
headers = {'accept': 'application/json'}

try:
    main()
except requests.exceptions.HTTPError as error_response:
    # Print the error
    print("***ERROR***")
    print(error_response)
    if error_response.response is not None:
        print("Error Messages:\n{}".format(json.dumps(error_response.response.json(), indent=4, separators=(',', ': '))))
```
This is how exceptions are handled in Python. If an exception is thrown in `main()`, execution stops, and the exception is caught here. In this case, we print the error. This is why having `main()` is useful. We can add many EcoAPI requests to `main()`, and the error handling is in the one location.

There is one other thing we need to do. We need to throw an exception when an error is returned from the EcoAPI. Python makes this easy. Add the following line after the call to `requests.get()`:
```python
response.raise_for_status()
```
To test this, use a bad password as follows:
```
python myFile.py -p "bad password"
```
The resulting EcoAPI error alerts you that the supplied credentials are invalid.

### The POST Request and Request Body
Now we create a filter list with a filter.

Create the `create_filter_list()` function after `get_resource()`:
```python
def get_resource(uri):
    ...

def create_filter_list(name, description, ipAddress):
    """
    Creates a filter list and a filter with the given information.
    Returns the created unique identifier. An exception is thrown if an error
    occurred.
    """
    # JSON request body
    filter_list_body = {
        "name": name,
        "description": description,
        "child": [
            {
                "filter": {
                    "ipAddress": ipAddress
                }
            }
        ]
    }

    # Make create request
    filter_list_uri = base_uri + "/filterList"
    print("\nCreating new filter list '{}' using URI:\n{}\n".format(filter_list_body["name"], filter_list_uri))
    response = requests.post(filter_list_uri, json=filter_list_body, auth=auth, headers=headers, verify=False)
    response.raise_for_status()

def main():
    ...
```
Looking at the POST request above, it requires the same arguments as the GET request with the addition of a request body.

To find the request body format for a specific resource in this guide (for example, [filter list](#tag/Filter-List)), click that resource on the left. You can see the different fields for all Stealth resources. Note that on the right side of each request is a response sample. You can select XML or JSON, and expand or minimize different portions of the response. Another way to find the request body format is to do a GET request and view the response.

Add the call to `create_filter_list()` to the beginning of `main()`:
```python
def main():
    # Create a filter list with a filter
    filter_list_name = "Test Python create"
    filter_list_desc = "This was created as part of the EcoAPI tutorial."
    filter_ipAddress = "1.1.1.1"
    created_filter_list_id = create_filter_list(filter_list_name, filter_list_desc, filter_ipAddress)

  # Get the filter lists
  ...
```
Save and run your program. Notice that the created filter list with the filter is returned and printed with the other filter lists. This verifies that the create request was successful.

So we are done right? We can make HTTP requests, see the response, construct and print JSON objects, and see any errors. There is just one more topic to cover: handling the request status.

### Request Status Handling
Some requests take longer than others and return a [request status](#tag/Request-Status) instead of the created resource. You will be alerted to the progress of your request. To find out what a specific request returns, you can use this guide, or make the request and see what is returned. You can also programmatically check the HTTP status code. If it is 202, Accepted, then a request status was returned.

After the create request we need to wait for the create to finish. Add the following to `create_filter_list()`:
```python
# Imports
...
import time
...

def create_filter_list(...):
    ...

    # Wait for the request to finish
    while request_status['finishedAt'] is None:
        time.sleep(2)
        request_status = get_resource(response.json()['uri'])
    print("Response: {}\n".format(json.dumps(request_status, indent=4, separators=(',', ': '))))
 ```
Notice we are making a get request but this time on the request status. We get the updated request status in a loop until the filter list create request is finished.

Save and run your program. Note that you will need to change the filter list name in `main()` because we already created a filter list with that name. Also, if you have a lot of filter lists, you may want to comment out the print statement in `main()` at this point.

You can see all the status messages. Note that we could have printed out new messages inside the loop (while the request is in progress), but we are printing out all the messages after the request is finished for simplicity.

Notice that in the printed request status, there is a createdResource field. Return the unique identifier of the created filter list from the request status as follows:
```python
def create_filter_list(...):
    ...

    # Get the created filter list ID
    id = None
    if request_status is not None:
        if len(request_status['createdResource']) > 0:
            id = request_status['createdResource'][0]['id']
            print("\nCreated resource unique identifier: " + id + "\n")
        else:
            print("\nThe request status does not contain created resources\n")
    return id
```
Now we can get and print just the created filter list with the filter, instead of all the filter lists. Add the variable, `created_filter_list_id`, to `main()`:
```python
main():
    ...
    created_filter_list_id = create_filter_list(filter_list_name, filter_list_desc, filter_ipAddress)

    # Get the created filter list with the filter
    uri = base_uri + '/filterList/' + created_filter_list_id
```
Save and run your finished program. Do not forget to change the filter list name. You can now see the created filter list printed out.

The advantage of writing your own scripts is automating your common scenarios or tasks that require more than one step. While this is not a programming tutorial, we hope it helps you get started with automating your Stealth tasks.

# General Information

This section contains general information that applies to all EcoAPI requests.

## Understanding a REST Request

A RESTful API request is comprised of four major components:

* URL
* Method
* Headers
* Body

**URL**: The URL identifies the resource and parameters for the request.

**Method**: The method is the type of request on the URL. There are four supported methods:

 * GET - used to read resources
 * POST - usually used to create a resource or make a resource request
 * PUT - usually used to update a resource, but in some cases used to create a resource
 * DELETE - used to remove a resource

**Headers**: Most requests require [authentication](#section/General-Information/Authentication-and-Authorization) which is provided via the `Authorization` header. The other two common headers are `Content-Type`, which describes the content of the payload body and `Accept`, which specifies what format the server should send the response in. Example values for both are `application/json` and `application/xml`.

**Body**: Some POST and PUT requests need to send data to the server such as for creating or updating a resource. A GET request returns data about a resource. Such data is known as the body of the request.

The following are examples of how to create a group using a JSON payload. The request is using a username/password combination of admin:admin123.

### Curl

```
curl -v -X POST https://localhost:8448/uisStealth/EcoApi/group \
-H 'Content-Type: application/json' \
-H 'Accept: application/json' \
-H 'Authorization: Basic YWRtaW46YWRtaW4=' \
-d '
{
  "name": "My Group",
  "description": "My Description"
}'
```

### PowerShell

```powershell
$uri = "https://localhost:8448/uisStealth/EcoApi/group"
$headers = @{
  Accept = 'application/json'
  Authorization = 'Basic YWRtaW46YWRtaW4='
}
$body = @"
{
  "name": "My Group",
  "description": "My Description"
}
"@
Invoke-RestMethod -Uri $uri -Headers $headers -Method Post -Body $body -ContentType "application/json"
```

If you are connecting to the Management Server remotely, and you are using the default self-signed certificate for the EcoAPI, you must select the Run as Administrator option for PowerShell, and you must override the certificate policy to ensure that certificate errors are ignored. See the following article for more information: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/11696944/powershell-v3-invoke-webrequest-https-error. The example PowerShell scripts override the certificate policy; see the `InitSecurity` function in the [ecoapi.ps1](./examples/powershell.ecoapi.ps1) script.

### Python

```python
import requests
uri = "https://localhost:8448/uisStealth/EcoApi/group"
headers = {
  'Accept':'application/json'
}
body = {
  "name": "My Group",
  "description": "My Description"
}
requests.post(uri,
  json=body,
  auth=('admin','admin123'),
  headers=headers)

```

### Ruby

```ruby
require 'net/http'
require 'uri'
require 'json'
uri = URI.parse("https://localhost:8448/uisStealth/EcoApi/group")
http = Net::HTTP.new(uri.host, uri.port)
http.use_ssl = true
headers = {
  'Accept' => 'application/json',
  'Content-Type' => 'application/json'
}
body = {
  'name' => 'My Group',
  'description' => 'My Description'
}
request = Net::HTTP::Post.new(uri.request_uri, headers)
request.basic_auth("admin", "admin123")
request.body = body.to_json
http.request(request)
```

## Base URI

You can access resources by making an HTTP request using the following base URI:

<pre>https://<Management Server computer name or IP address>:<port number>/uisStealth/EcoApi</pre>

The default port number is 8448; however, you might have specified a different port number when you installed the Management Server software.

For example, if you are accessing the EcoAPI from the Management Server using the default port, you can use the following base URI:

<pre>https://localhost:8448/uisStealth/EcoApi</pre>

The provided examples assume that the **baseUri** variable is set to the base URI. For example, the PowerShell scripts assume the following statement:

```powershell
$baseUri = 'https://localhost:8448/uisStealth/EcoApi'
```

## API Version

After defining the base URI, an API version can be defined. If an API version is not specified, version 1 is assumed. Note that only version 1 is currently supported.

The API version is not the same as the Stealth version. The Stealth version determines resources, fields, and the types of requests that can be made, while the API version defines the behavior or the request and the data that is returned to the user. Additional information on behavior changes for a particular resource can be found in that resource's section.

To define the API version, use the following URI:

<pre>https://<Management Server computer name or IP address>:<port number>/uisStealth/EcoApi/v<API version></pre>

For example, to use API version 1, use **/v1**; therefore, the following is the full URI to use API version 1:

<pre>https://localhost:8448/uisStealth/EcoApi/v1</pre>

It is possible to access the latest API version using **/latest**. For example, the following is the full URI with the latest API version:

<pre>https://localhost:8448/uisStealth/EcoApi/latest</pre>

## Resource Path

In the sections that describe the resources, the resource URI is relative to the base URI; therefore, the full URI includes the base URI plus the resource URI. For example:

<pre>https://<Management Server computer name or IP address>:<port number>/uisStealth/EcoApi/v<API version>/<resource path></pre>

For example, the Version resource uses the resource path **/version**; therefore, the full URI to access the Version resource is:

<pre>https://localhost:8448/uisStealth/EcoApi/v1/version</pre>

## Query Parameters

You can optionally add query parameters to a request, as follows:

<pre>https://localhost:8448/uisStealth/EcoApi/v<API version>/<resource path>?<query parameter>=<value>[&<query parameter>=<value>]...</pre>

The sections that describe the resources identify the allowed query parameters for each request, and the types of values allowed for each parameter.

## Authentication and Authorization

The EcoAPI uses HTTP basic authentication which uses the HTTP header `Authorization: Basic <encoded user:password>`

 The `<encoded user:password>` contains the user name and password, separated by a colon, and encoded using Base64 encoding. The method that you use to make an EcoAPI request depends on the type of application. For example:

* A web browser displays a dialog box to enter the user name and password.

* The curl utility uses the -u option to enter the user name, and curl prompts you for the password.

* In PowerShell, you can provide the encoded Authorization header entry (see the example later in this topic).

For more details on basic authentication, see <https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2617>.

After a user is authenticated, the EcoAPI looks up the [Administrator user role](#tag/Admin-Role) assigned to that user and either permits or disallows the request based on the role. Each request identifies the roles that are permitted to make the request.

### Supplying Credentials Using PowerShell

There are several ways to supply the necessary credentials using PowerShell. One way is to set the **Authorization** HTTP header:

```
$username = "your-user-name"
$password = "your-password"
$combo = [System.Text.Encoding]::ASCII.GetBytes("$username`:$password")
$encoded = [System.Convert]::ToBase64String($combo)
$headers = @{ Authorization = "Basic $encoded" ; Accept = "application/xml"}
```

Once the header is set, you can pass it to the **Invoke-RestMethod** or **Invoke-WebRequest** cmdlet:

```
$result = Invoke-RestMethod -Headers $headers . . .
```

Another mechanism is to use the **Get-Credential** cmdlet to display a dialog box where you can enter your username and password; it returns a credential object. Pass the credential to the **Invoke-RestMethod** or **Invoke-WebRequest** cmdlet:

```
$cred = Get-Credential
$result = Invoke-WebRequest -Credential $cred . . .
```

In the PowerShell examples for the resources that are provided in this guide, the code to get credentials or build the HTTP headers is implied and is not repeated; however, the examples do assume the existence of the $**header** or $**cred** variable. Note that you can use either variable, regardless of which one appears in the example.

### Supplying Credentials Using Python

There are several libraries available in Python for making HTTPS requests. The recommended method is to use the **Requests** package that can be installed using **pip**. Once this package is installed, credentials can be passed to the various methods of the **requests** module as follows:

```python
import requests
import getpass
username = input('Enter user name: ')
password = getpass.getpass('Enter password: ')
result = requests.get(requestUri, auth=(username, password), verify=False, ...)
result = requests.post(requestUri, auth=(username, password), verify=False, ...)
```

Requests can ignore verifying the SSL certificate by setting **verify=False**.

## Media Types

Tools that use the RESTful API must accept or send data using the following media types:

* application/xml

* application/json

A tool can identify the request media type using the **Content-Type** HTTP header, and specify the desired response media type using the **Accept** HTTP header.

## HTTP Status Codes

The application you create or customize should be configured to handle the following HTTP status codes:

* 200 OK - The typical status returned when there are no problems.

* 201 Created - Returned by the API for a create request that is not handled asynchronously.  The API returns the created object.

* 202 Accepted - Returned by the API for an asynchronous request that is processed in the background.  The API returns a [Request Status](#tag/Request-Status) object that can be used to track the progress of the request.

* 204 No Content - The request was successfully processed and no data is returned. This is a typical response code for a delete request and for an update request when nothing has changed.

* 400 Bad Request - The request is invalid or contains invalid data. For example, a field might contain a value that does not meet the validation requirements.

* 401 Unauthorized - No credentials were supplied and the request requires credentials, or the credentials that were supplied do not allow the request.

* 403 Forbidden - The user has failed more than five consecutive log in attempts and the user's computer is locked out of the EcoAPI for 15 minutes. No error text accompanies this status code.

* 404 Not Found - The request was made for a specific resource, but there is no resource with the supplied unique identifier.

* 405 Method Not Allowed - The method used (for example, DELETE) is not valid for the given URI.

* 406 Not Acceptable - The media type is not application/xml or application/json.

* 408 Request Timeout - The API failed to respond within a given time as set by the application making the call.

* 500 Internal Server Error - An unexpected error occurred in the API. Usually this indicates a coding or configuration issue that needs to be corrected by a developer or administrator.

## Error Results

If an error status code (400 or greater) is returned by the server, the entity returned is as follows:

```xml
<errors>
  <error>
    <key>error key</key>
    <message>error text</message>
  </error>
  . . .
</errors>
```

Where

* **key** is an integer that identifies the error message. Refer to the _Unisys Stealth Log Entry Definition Guide_, which is available from the [Stealth Support website Documentation page](https://www.support.unisys.com/common/epa/DocumentationLibraries.aspx?PLA=st3&NAV=st3), for a complete list of error messages.

* **message** is the text of the error. The message appears in the language specified by the `Accept-Language` HTTP Header if a translation has been provided for the indicated language. Refer to the _Unisys Stealth Information Center_, which is available from the [Stealth Support website Documentation page](https://www.support.unisys.com/common/epa/DocumentationLibraries.aspx?PLA=st3&NAV=st3), for details on providing error message translations.

In most cases, only a single error is returned; however, in some cases (such as input validation), multiple errors are returned.

### Errors Reported by Tomcat

Some errors are reported by Tomcat in HTML. The following are some scenarios where this occurs:

* When you specify a resource in the URI that does not exist or is misspelled; for example, **/filterset**

* When you make a request that is not supported for a resource; for example, PUT

* In some cases, when you provide an incorrect type for a field; for example, entering "abc" in a Boolean field using JSON

* When you provide an incorrect child resource; for example, entering a qualifier in the following example:

```xml
<configuration>
  <name>configuration name</name>
  <roles>
    <role>
      <name>role name</name>
    </role>
    <qualifier>
      <name>qualifier name</name>
    </qualifier>
  </roles>
</configuration>
```

### Handling Errors Using PowerShell

When the PowerShell script uses the **Invoke-RestMethod** or **Invoke-WebRequest** cmdlet to make a request, and the server returns an error, the cmdlet throws an exception. Therefore, to view the HTTP status code or error messages, the script must catch the exception. The following example shows how to handle an error, including getting the HTTP status code and the error messages. It also shows how to handle Tomcat errors in HTML.

```powershell
try {
  $result = InvokeRestMethod . . .
} catch {
    $errorResponse = $_.Exception.Response
    if ($errorResponse) {
        # The <errors> XML appears a byte stream, read it and convert to XML object
        $stream = $errorResponse.GetResponseStream()
        $xmlErrors = [System.Text.Encoding]::UTF8.GetString($stream.GetBuffer(), 0, $stream.Length)

        if ($xmlErrors -like "*<errors><error>*") {
            # EcoAPI returned an <errors> object
            [xml]$errors = $xmlErrors

            # Now that we have the entity, print out the status code and all of the errors
            [int]$status = $errorResponse.StatusCode
            "HTTP status: $status ($($errorResponse.StatusDescription))"
            "Messages:"
            $errors.errors.error | foreach { " $($_.key): $($_.message)" }
        } else {
            # Tomcat returned an HTML error message
            Write-Host $xmlErrors
        }
    }
}
```

### Handling Errors Using Python

When using the **Requests** package to make a request, you can tell the response object to throw an exception when the server returns an HTTP error. The following example shows how to handle an error, including getting the HTTP status code and the error messages:

```python
import requests
import json

try:
   result = requests.post(requestUri, auth=(username, password), headers={'accept': 'application/json'})
   result.raise_for_status()
except requests.exceptions.HTTPError as errorResponse:
   print("The request received an error with status code: {0}".format(errorResponse.response.status_code))
   if errorResponse.response.text != None:
      try:
         print("Error Messages:")
         if errorResponse.response.headers['Content-Type'] == "application/json":
            errData = json.loads(errorResponse.response.text)
            errors = errData['error']
            if errors != None:
               for err in errors:
                  errKey = err['key']
                  errMsg = err['message']
                  print("[{0}]: {1}".format(errKey, errMsg))
         elif errorResponse.response.headers['Content-Type'] == "application/xml":
            root = ET.fromstring(errorResponse.response.text)
            errors = root.findall('error')
            if len(errors) > 0:
               for err in errors:
                  errKey = err.find('key').text
                  errMsg = err.find('message').text
                  print("[{0}]: {1}".format(errKey, errMsg))
      except requests.exceptions.RequestException as e:
         print("Unable to get messages -- " + e)
except requests.exceptions.RequestException as e:
   # Handle other exceptions
   ...
```

## Password Handling

When including a password as part of the data of a create or update request, such as when creating a Stealth(aware) Authentication Set, the tool making the request must encrypt the password using a public key and encode the results using Base64 encoding. This section describes how to do this for several scripting languages.

First, you must obtain the public key for the Management certificate, which is used to encrypt sensitive data stored in the configuration database. You can do this by exporting the Management certificate from the Windows user certificate store on the Management Server. When exporting the certificate, do not include the private key. You can also use the [Export-MgmtCert.ps1](./examples/powershell/Export-MgmtCert.ps1) example PowerShell script to export the Management certificate. Refer to the _Unisys Stealth Information Center_ for more information regarding the Management certificate.

_**Note:** The self-signed Management certificate created when Stealth is installed has the same name as the  user who was logged into the Management Server and installed the Management Server software. Once exported, the contents of the certificate file should look similar to the following:_

<pre>-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----
MIID8DCCAligAwIBAgIQGxCDsgS9CbNBeYH+vYoPETANBgkqhkiG9w0BAQUFADAq
MRYwFAYDVQQDEw1zZXJ2aWNlYWNjdGVtMRAwDgYDVQQLEwdTdGVhbHRoMB4XDTE4
. . .
cWR9jq/wR5gaFzEDRv4s+/oBPLZnqQUxjcXJTBwXAvYk0KjBl4mn4TlqQ1F3O9XU
O1BpPA==
-----END CERTIFICATE-----
</pre>


The certificate must be available in a file that can be read by the script. For purposes of the example scripts below, assume the file is located in the current working directory and is named **em-public.cer.** Note that you should adapt the following examples as required for your environment. There are many ways to properly encrypt and Base64 encode a password in most programming and scripting languages that you can use, depending on your requirements.

### Password Handling in PowerShell

The following example shows how to encrypt and encode a password and include it in the XML for an Authorization Set:

```powershell
$certFile = 'em-public.cer'
$cert = New-Object System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509Certificate2($certFile)

$password = 'AdminPortal1#'
$bytes = [System.Text.Encoding]::UTF8.GetBytes($password)
# Set OAEP Padding option to false
$encrypted = $cert.PublicKey.Key.Encrypt($bytes, $false)
# Make it little-endian
[array]::Reverse($encrypted)
# Base64 encode the encrypted password
$securePassword = [Convert]::ToBase64String($encrypted)

$authXml = @"
<authorization>
    <id>265c61a8-6346-462d-a931-5d48c0ea0da5</id>
    <name>Authorization Example</name>
    . . .
    <ldap>
        <address>LDAP://ldap.server:3268/DC=mycompany,DC=com</address>
        <useSsl>true</useSsl>
        <username>portaladmin</username>
        <password>$securePassword</password>
    </ldap>
</authorization>
"@
```

### Password Handling in Python

The following example shows how to encrypt and encode a password in Python. In this example, the cryptography module is used to handle encryption.

```python
import base64
from cryptography import x509
from cryptography.hazmat.backends import default_backend
from cryptography.hazmat.primitives import hashes
from cryptography.hazmat.primitives.asymmetric import padding

certFile = "em-public.cer"
cert = x509.load_der_x509_certificate(open(certFile,"rb").read(), default_backend())
key = cert.public_key()

password = "AdminPortal1#"
bytes = password.encode("utf-8")
# Use PKCS padding scheme
encryptedPw = key.encrypt(bytes, padding.PKCS1v15())
# Make it little-endian
bytearr = bytearray(encryptedPw)
bytearr.reverse()
# Base64 encode the encrypted password
encodedPassword = base64.b64encode(bytearr)
# Convert from bytes to a string
securePassword = encodedPassword.decode("utf-8")

$authJSON = {
  id:"265c61a8-6346-462d-a931-5d48c0ea0da5",
  name:"Authorization Example",
  . . .
  ldap:{
      address:"LDAP://ldap.server:3268/DC=mycompany,DC=com",
      useSsl:true,
      username:"portaladmin",
      password:securePassword
  }}

```

## Scheduling Requests

Requests that are marked as `schedulable` can be scheduled to run at some point in the future. To schedule a request, provide a `runAt` query parameter with an ISO 8601 formatted date; for example:

<pre>https://localhost:8448/uisStealth/EcoApi/v<API version>/<resource path>?runAt=2019-11-06T17:48:41Z</pre>

Supplying an improperly formatted date will result in an error. Due to possible system clock inaccuracies, requests that are scheduled to run only minutes into the past or future may execute immediately. This threshold can be modified in the ecoapi properties file and by default is set to 3 minutes. If a request is scheduled to execute too far into the past, an error will be returned.

When you schedule a request, the API returns a [Request Status](#tag/Request-Status) that can be used to track its progress.

In addition to scheduling requests, you can specify a logical identifier to group related requests with one another. For example, say you've written a script to load a Stealth(aware) Solution, which has a Deployment ID of 1. When you schedule a request to provision this Solution, you can also supply a Deployment ID of 1 to correlate the request with the Solution; for example:

<pre>https://localhost:8448/uisStealth/EcoApi/v<API version>/<resource path>?runAt=2019-11-06T17:48:41Z&deploymentId=1</pre>

This allows you to do things such as view which request statuses provisioned a solution with a certain Deployment ID.

## PowerShell cmdlets

The Unisys.Stealth.EcoAPI PowerShell module can be used to interact with the Unisys Stealth EcoAPI. This module deals with all the resources and requests exposed via EcoAPI.

The [Unisys.Stealth.EcoAPI cmdlets](./ecoapi-powershell-docs/Unisys.Stealth/Unisys.Stealth.EcoApi/index.html) support standard PowerShell features such as pipelining, discovering and specifying parameters, and handling results. The cmdlets provide a convenient mechanism to make ad-hoc EcoAPI requests and can be used in scripts without having to handle the details of working with a REST API.

_**Note:** You must run [Connect-StealthServer](./ecoapi-powershell-docs/Unisys.Stealth/Unisys.Stealth.EcoApi/Connect-StealthServer.html) to connect to the Management Server before running other commands such as [New-StealthEndpointInspection](./ecoapi-powershell-docs/Unisys.Stealth/Unisys.Stealth.EcoApi/New-StealthEndpointInspection.html)._

If you need to run these cmdlets on another system besides the Management Server, do the following:

1. On the Management Server, navigate to <code><_Stealth program directory_>\Unisys\EnterpriseMgmt\EcoAPI\automation\modules</code>, and copy the `Unisys.Stealth.EcoAPI` folder.

2. If your organization's security policy enables you to update the `C:\Program Files\WindowsPowerShell\Modules` directory, paste the **Unisys.Stealth.EcoAPI** folder into the `C:\Program Files\WindowsPowerShell\Modules` directory on the system that you want to use EcoAPI cmdlets.

  If your security policy does not enable you to update the `C:\Program Files\WindowsPowerShell\Modules` directory, do the following:

    a. Determine a module location that is appropriate for your organization's security policies.

      _**Note:** PowerShell modules can be placed anywhere on a system, but it is simplest to use a directory that is            already in your **PSModulePath** environment variable.            However, if necessary, you can add a new location to **PSModulePath**.            For more information, see https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/microsoft.powershell.core/about/about_modules?view=powershell-6._

    b. Paste the **Unisys.Stealth.EcoAPI* folder into the **PSModulePath** location.

3. Enter `Import-Module Unisys.Stealth.EcoAPI` at the top your script.

# General Request Conventions

The EcoAPI has several conventions that govern its behavior. Any exceptions are noted in the individual request's documentation.

## Data Handling During Update

This section describes common update request scenarios. You can combine all the scenarios in a single request or use separate requests. For example, you can change both the description of a filter set and identify the child filter lists that belong to the filter set in a single request, or make two separate requests.

### Resource Unique Identifier Is Ignored

The body of an update request does not need to include the unique identifier of the resource being updated. Instead, the unique identifier is passed as part of the request URI. For example, the URI to update a role with a unique identifier of _243247BB-299A-4372-A888-F6538D77DF0D_ looks like this:

`https://localhost:8448/uisStealth/EcoApi/role/243247BB-299A-4372-A888-F6538D77DF0D`

### Null and Blank Data Handling During Update

An update request updates the resource with attributes included in the request and retains the existing information for fields not included in the request.

For example, if you update a filter list and only include the **name** field, only the name is updated. Note that a field is also not updated if the value in the request matches the existing value in the Enterprise Manager database.

Here is an example for updating just the name:

```xml
<filterList>
  <name>My new name</name>
</filterList>
```

The equivalent in JSON would be:

```
{
  "name" : "My new name"
}
```

To remove the data value for a non-required field, or reset it to its default, pass an empty value in the request. For example, if you want to remove the description from a user, pass an empty <description> value.

Here is an example for removing the description of a user:

```xml
<user>
  <description></description>
</user>
```

The equivalent in JSON would be:

```
{
  "description" : ""
}
```

Note that when you query a resource, the response might not contain fields that have no values. For example, if you query the user resource, the description field might not appear.

### Referencing Other Resources During an Update

During an update request, you can only reference existing resources. Only the unique identifiers of these existing resources are used; that is, any other data passed with those resources is ignored. Therefore, an update request uses the resources as-is, which means that you can neither modify nor create referenced resources as part of an update request.

_**Note:** Some resources support requests that allow you to add or remove associations using sub-resource URLs. For example, you can use the [Add User to Role](#operation/addUserToRole) request to associate a user to a role instead of making an [Update Role](#operation/updateRole) request._

#### Adding and Removing Associations

To add or remove a relationship, provide the desired final state of the field. When adding a new association to another resource, if the resource already includes other referencing resources, you must include all existing resources in the update request. You cannot simply specify the new resource you want to add; doing so would result in the other associations being removed. Therefore, you need to identify all of the children.

Similarly, when removing an association, you must include all resources you want to retain.

For example, assume there is a role that has three COIs associated with it:

```xml
<role>
  <cois>
    <coi><id>1</id></coi>
    <coi><id>2</id></coi>
    <coi><id>3</id></coi>
  </cois>
</role>
```

To add a fourth COI with a unique identifier of 4, we must include the existing ones:

```xml
<role>
  <cois>
    <coi><id>1</id></coi>
    <coi><id>2</id></coi>
    <coi><id>3</id></coi>
    <coi><id>4</id></coi>
  </cois>
</role>

```

To remove a COI, we must include the ones we want to keep. Thus, to remove the COI with a unique identifier of 3, we pass this body:

```xml
<role>
  <cois>
    <coi><id>1</id></coi>
    <coi><id>2</id></coi>
    <coi><id>4</id></coi>
  </cois>
</role>
```

Note that we could have added COI 3 and removed COI 4 in a single request by passing the final body.

To remove all of the COIs, the request body must contain an empty list:

```xml
<role>
  <cois></cois>
</role>
```

#### Reordering Associations

To reorder associations, provide the desired final state of the field. Thus, provide the associations in the correct order.

Using the previous example, to reverse the order of the COIs, use this request body:

```xml
<role>
  <cois>
    <coi><id>4</id></coi>
    <coi><id>2</id></coi>
    <coi><id>1</id></coi>
  </cois>
</role>
```

## Force Deletion

The request to delete a resource will fail if it is in use. You can override this behavior by providing the `force=true` query parameter. When provided, the resource will first be disassociated from all other resources and then deleted.

For example, assume there is a  COI that is referenced by multiple roles. A `DELETE /coi/{id}` request will fail with an in-use error. But a `DELETE /coi/{id}?force=true` request will first disassociate the COI from all the roles and then delete the COI.

## Resource Reference Handling

Many resources reference other resources. For example, a filter set can contain a number of filter lists. Some requests apply to both the resource and its referenced resources. This section describes how referenced resources are handled for such requests.

### GET Request

On a `GET` request, by default only the **id** field of a referenced resource is provided. To include all fields of referenced resources, the `recursive=true` query parameter must be provided.

For example, `GET /filterSet` returns the details of the filter set and the unique identifiers of each filter list that belongs to the filter set. However, `GET /filterSet?recursive=true` returns the details of the filter set and the details of each filter list that belongs to the filter set, as well as all of the filters and filter lists belonging to those filter lists, including all of their referenced filter lists, filters, qualifiers and qualifier filters.

_**Note:** Specifying `recursive=true` may negatively impact performance and memory usage, especially if the resource contains a deeply nested set of referenced resources._

### DELETE Request

On a `DELETE` request, by default only the specified resource will be deleted. If the `recursive=true` query parameter is specified, each child resource is also deleted along  with any children of those resources. If combined with the [force](#section/General-Request-Conventions/Force-Deletion) query parameter, each child  resource is deleted, even if the child is in use.

For example, `DELETE /filterSet/{id}` deletes the identified filter set (assuming it is not in use); it doesn't delete any of its referenced filter lists. However, `DELETE /filterSet/{id}?recursive=true` deletes the identified filter set as well as its child filter lists, and any referenced filter lists, filters, qualifiers and qualifier filters, provided that they are not in use. A `DELETE /filterSet/{id}?recursive=true&force=true` request deletes all of them even if they are in use.

# Validation

This section describes the validation performed for various data types. The fields for a resource are validated when the resource is created or updated. This section also identifies the expected formatting in various fields when querying the resource.

## Certificate Names

The value of a certificate name must meet the following criteria:

* Can be a maximum of 64 characters
* Can start with a letter, number or special character
* Can contain special characters but cannot contain any of the following special characters:
  * plus sign (+)
  * semicolon (;)
  * comma (,)

## Date and Time

Date and time values must be formatted using the ISO 8601 standard, and it is highly recommended that you use the UTC time zone.

The following is the format of the ISO 8601 standard, where T is used to separate the date and time, and Z is used to indicate the UTC time zone.

`yyyy-MM-ddTHH:mm:ss:SSSZ`

To specify a timezone offset, it can either be plus or minus followed by HH:mm.

`yyyy-MM-ddTHH:mm:ss:SSSHH:mm`

See <https://www.w3.org/TR/NOTE-datetime> for more details on the ISO 8601 standard.

## Descriptions

The value of a description field must meet the following criteria:

* Can be a maximum of 255 characters
* Can contain letters and numbers
* Can contain special characters but cannot contain any of the following special characters:
  * forward slash (/)
  * double quotation mark (")
  * angle brackets (<>)

## Domain Names

The value of a domain name or a fully qualified host name must meet the following criteria:

* Can be a maximum of 255 characters
* Must start with a letter, number, or underscore
* Must end with a letter, number, or underscore
* Cannot have two periods in a row
* Can contain letters and numbers
* Can contain any of these special characters:
  * hyphen (-)
  * period (.)
  * underscore (_)

Refer to the [Microsoft documentation, DNS Domain Names section](https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/help/909264/naming-conventions-in-active-directory-for-computers-domains-sites-and-ous), for more information.

## Group Names

The value of an Active Directory group name field must meet the following criteria:

* Can be a maximum of 64 characters
* Must match an existing Active Directory group name
* Must start with a letter
* Can contain letters and numbers
* Can contain special characters but cannot contain any of these special characters:
  * pound sign (#)
  * comma (,)
  * plus sign (+)
  * double quotation mark (")
  * backslash (\)
  * angle brackets (<>)
  * semicolon (;)

## IDs
In general, unique identifier (ID) values are created by the Enterprise Manager and provided in the **id**  field of the response entity. Therefore, when supplying a unique identifier, the script typically uses the value it obtained from a prior query.

For example, when creating a filter list with an embedded qualifier, the script first queries the qualifier and then provides the resulting unique identifier to identify the embedded qualifier.

In the event that the client script must supply a unique identifier when creating an object, (for example, when creating a Stealth(aware) Profile), it is highly recommend that you use a Universally Unique Identifier (UUID). The following text describes how to obtain a UUID in various languages:

For PowerShell:
```powershell
$id = [guid]::NewGuid()
````
For Python:
```python
import uuid
id = str(uuid.uuid4())
```

For Ruby:
```ruby
require 'securerandom'
id = str(uuid.uuid4())
```
## IP Address

The value of an IP address field must contain one of the following:

* A single IPv4 or IPv6 address
* A range of IPv4 or IPv6 addresses, which is a pair of IP addresses separated by a hyphen (-), where the second IP address in the pair is greater than or equal to the first.
* An IPv4 or IPv6 address in CIDR notation
* An asterisk (*), which means any IP address

The following are examples of allowed IP addresses:

| Value Type               | IPv4 Example                | IPv6 Example               |
|--------------------------|-----------------------------|----------------------------|
| Single address           | 192.168.1.100               | fe80::102a:cbc6:939b:709e  |
| Address range            | 192.168.1.100-192.168.1.150 | fe80::7000-fe80::7fff      |
| Address in CIDR notation | 192.168.0.0/16              | fe80::102a:cbc6:939b:0/112 |

## Names

The value of a name field must meet the following criteria:

* Can be a maximum of 28 characters, unless indicated otherwise
* Must start with a letter
* Can contain letters, numbers and spaces (but cannot end in a space nor have multiple spaces in a row)
* Can contain any of these special characters:
  * underscore (_)
  * hyphen (-)
  * comma (,)
  * period (.); however, multiple periods in a row are not supported
  * exclamation point (!)
  * dollar sign ($)
  * percent sign (%)
  * ampersand (&)
  * single quotation mark (')
  * grave accent (`); also known as a backtick
  * parentheses ()
  * equal sign (=)
  * at sign (@)
  * square brackets ([])
  * caret (^)
  * curly brackets ({})
  * tilde (~)

## Object Identifier

The value of an [Object Identifier](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Object_identifier) (OID) must meet the following criteria:

* Must start with a number greater than 0
* Must end with a number greater than 0
* Can consist of any number of numerical values separated by periods.
 The following is the smallest example allowed: 1.1

The following are the Unisys default values:

* Enhanced Key Usage (Computer Name Authorization) - 1.3.6.1.4.1.223.52.1.1
* Enhanced Key Usage (User Name Authorization) - 1.3.6.1.4.1.223.52.1.2

## Password

The value of a password field must be encrypted using the Management certificate. In addition, the encrypted password must be Base64 encoded. Refer to [Password Handling](#section/General-Information/Password-Handling) for more information.

Note that the password is never returned as part of a read request; the password field is used only during a create or update request.

## Network Protocol

The value of a protocol field must be one of the following:

* An integer from 1 to 254
* UDP, which is the same as 17
* TCP, which is the same as 6
* \* or 255, which are both wildcards that mean any protocol

## Server Port

The value of a port field must be one of the following:

* An integer from 1 to 65535, which identifies a port number
* A range of ports which is two port numbers separated by a hyphen (for example, 2000-2999). The second port number must be greater than or equal to the first.
* \* or 0, which are both wildcards that mean any port or the port range 1-65535

## User Names

The value of a user name must meet the following criteria:

* Can be a maximum of 104 characters
* Can contain letters, numbers, and spaces
* Must not start or end with spaces
* Can contain special characters but cannot contain any of these special characters:
  * double quotation mark (")
  * forward slash (/)
  * backslash (\)
  * square brackets ([])
  * colon (:)
  * semicolon (;)
  * vertical bar (|)
  * equal sign (=)
  * comma (,)
  * plus sign (+)
  * asterisk (*)
  * question mark (?)
  * angle brackets (<>)

Refer to the [Microsoft documentation](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/bb726984.aspx) for more information.

# Troubleshooting

This section provides suggestions and workarounds for common issues you might encounter when using the EcoAPI.

## Resolving an Out of Memory Error

When using the EcoAPI to read configurations, roles, COIs, filter sets, filter lists, or qualifiers, if the Enterprise Manager database contains many instances of those objects, and if the **recursive** parameter is set to true for the read request, the request might result in an out of memory error. As a workaround for this issue, you can do either of the following:

* Make the read requests with the **recursive** parameter set to **false**.

  That is, make one request to get the parent object, and then make separate requests for each of the children, and separate requests for each of their children, and so on. For example, to get a full filter set tree, you would first read the filter set with recursive set to false. The result contains the unique identifiers of the child filter lists, which can be used to read each filter list, again with recursive set to false. That result contains the unique identifiers of the child filter lists and qualifiers, which can be used to read those objects.

* Increase the allocated heap size for the EcoAPI by doing the following:
  1. Open Windows PowerShell using the Run as Administrator option.
  2. Change to the *<Stealth data files directory>*\ProgramData\Unisys\SetupEM directory.
  3. Enter the following command to determine the current heap size:

   ```.\Check-EcoAPI.ps1 -heap 0```
  4. Decide on a new heap size.

   _**Note:** Unisys recommends that you make the heap size 1024 MB or larger._

  5. Enter the following command to set a new heap size, where <size> is expressed in megabytes:

   ```.\Check-EcoAPI.ps1 -heap <size>```

   For example, if the current heap size is 2048 megabytes, increase it to 2560 megabytes by entering the following command:

   ```.\Check-EcoAPI.ps1 -heap 2560```
